item.title: IHT Rendezvous: What Would a President Romney Mean for the Arab Spring? For Europe?
item.description: Whether Barack Obama is re-elected or Mitt Romney becomes the 45th president of the United States, the challenges of the Arab Spring will be there to confront either man. In addition, a President Romney might have some international fences to mend.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARCUS MABRY

item.title: Bin Laden Book’s Navy Author Was Slighted, Account Says
item.description: A new e-book says that Matt Bissonnette, a former Navy SEALs member who wrote a first-person account of the Osama bin Laden raid, was willing to speak out because of “bad blood” with his unit.
item.category: No Easy Day: The Firsthand Account of the Mission That Killed Osama bin Laden (Book)
item.dc:creator: By JAMES DAO

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In China, a Ferrari Crashes and the Party Quakes
item.description: The mysterious crash of a Ferrari in Beijing last March is now having repercussions at the highest levels of the Chinese Communist Party. President Hu Jintao's chief aide has been effectively sidelined --- his son died in the crash --- amid allegations of an elaborate coverup and questions about how the young man could have afforded the $788,000 car.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MCDONALD

item.title: Muslims Enroll at Catholic Colleges in Growing Numbers
item.description: More Muslims have enrolled in Roman Catholic colleges in the United States in recent years, with students saying they prefer a place where religious talk and observance are encouraged.
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
item.media:credit: Ty William Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Hadil Issa and Nada and Marwa Alsaif at the University of Dayton, a Roman Catholic university.

item.title: Evaluating Schools on Gay Rights
item.description: While much of the information could be found independently, the Web site Gay by Degree has created a searchable database and given the issue greater prominence.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE

item.title: University's Non-E.U. Students Face Deportation
item.description: London Metropolitan University has lost the right to admit overseas students, leaving thousands in limbo.
item.dc:creator: By D.D. GUTTENPLAN

item.title: Pakistani Blasphemy Case Shifts as Cleric Is Arrested
item.description: The Muslim cleric who had expressed anger at a Christian girl’s alleged desecration of sacred Muslim texts has been accused by a colleague of falsifying evidence.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: The police escorted Mr. Chisti in a blindfold from a hearing in Islamabad on Saturday.

item.title: News Analysis: In Afghanistan, Hitting Pause on Local Police Training
item.description: A decision to suspend the training of new Afghan Local Police recruits was the first tap on the brakes for one of the most controversial programs in the Afghan security plan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and GRAHAM BOWLEY
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Afghan Local Police patrolled near Sangsar in Afghanistan in April. Training for the program has been suspended and rescreenings are planned.

item.title: U.S. Is Weighing New Curbs on Iran in Nod to Israel
item.description: The Obama administration is taking steps it hopes will force Iran to reconsider almost stalemated nuclear negotiations — and forestall an Israeli attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: U.S. Companies Conduct Fire Drills in Case Greece Exits Euro
item.description: Even as Greece desperately tries to avoid defaulting on its debt, American firms are preparing for what was once unthinkable: that Greece may soon be forced to leave the euro zone.
item.category: Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana SA|IBRLF|other-OTC
item.dc:creator: By NELSON D. SCHWARTZ

item.title: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, 92, Unification Church Founder, Dies
item.description: The Korean evangelist’s Unification Church was notable for mass weddings, fresh-faced proselytizers and links to vast commercial interests.
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL J. WAKIN
item.media:description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, right, with his wife, Hak Ja Han, married 2,075 couples at Madison Square Garden in 1982.

item.title: Tutu Says Bush and Blair Should Face Court Over Iraq
item.description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu wrote that the two former leaders should be made to “answer for their actions” in the 2003 invasion of Iraq.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Despite Eviction, Settlers of West Bank Outpost Hold Fast to Mission
item.description: Following a court order, Israeli authorities evacuated 47 families from the Migron settlement, which the Supreme Court ruled had been built on land owned by Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli police officers removed a protester from a house in Migron. Israel’s Supreme Court ordered the evacuation of the outpost.

item.title: Egypt Abuzz as Woman in Hijab Reads News on State TV
item.description: The appearance is said to be the first of a veiled news presenter on state television, which had enforced a de facto ban during the Mubarak era.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:credit: Egyptian TV, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Fatma Nabil is said to be the first anchor to wear a hijab on Egyptian state television.

item.title: Gen. William W. Momyer, Celebrated Pilot, Dies at 95
item.description: General Momyer was a famed World War II fighter pilot who would go on to command aerial combat and bombing operations during the early years of the Vietnam War.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN
item.media:description: William M. Momyer, then a three-star general, in 1967.

item.title: Rebels Bomb Heavily Guarded Neighborhood in Damascus
item.description: Rebels set off two bombs amid military buildings in the Syrian capital Sunday, as the new United Nations envoy to the country refused to call for President Bashar al-Assad to step down.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Venezuela Finds No Sign of Reported Massacre
item.description: Venezuelan officials who traveled to the Amazon to investigate a report of a mass killing in an indigenous community have found no evidence of any killings, government officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Afghan Villagers Protest Vengeful Militias
item.description: Villagers near Kunduz say a pro-government militia killed 11 people in the second recent case of reprisal killings of Afghans believed to be Taliban sympathizers.
item.dc:creator: By ABDUL MATIN SARFRAZ and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Men gathered on Sunday by the bodies of victims of a weekend assault in the village of Kanam. The villagers blamed one of the militia group known as arbakai.

item.title: Mexico City Journal: Mexico City’s Aztec Past Keeps Emerging in the Present
item.description: Mexico City might be one of the world’s classic megacities, but it is also an archaeological wonder, with surprises still being uncovered in the city’s superimposed layers.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN and SOFIA CASTELLO Y TICKELL
item.media:credit: National Institute of Anthropology and History, via Reuters
item.media:description: Archaeologists removed human bones, among nearly 2,000, including 10 skulls, found recently at the Templo Mayor site.

item.title: South Africa Lifts Charges of Murder in Mine Strike
item.description: Prosecutors provisionally dropped murder charges against the 270 miners who had been accused of killing 34 of their own colleagues when the police opened fire on them during a strike.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN

item.title: In Pivotal Week for Euro Debt Crisis, a Test for Mario Draghi
item.description: Some analysts say Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank’s president, might have a difficult time convincing investors that the bank will take decisive action against the euro debt crisis.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: U.S. Halting Program to Train Afghan Recruits
item.description: Training of Afghan Local Police and special operations forces has been put on hold to better screen out threats to troops, officials say.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By GRAHAM BOWLEY and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.

item.title: Kurt Maetzig, German Film Director, Is Dead at 101
item.description: Mr. Maetzig, a pioneering figure in East Germany’s socialist film industry after World War II, helped postwar Germany come to terms with its Nazi past.
item.dc:creator: By SAM DILLON
item.media:description: The German director Kurt Maetzig said he had never considered leaving East Germany, even when colleagues in the film industry were defecting to the West.

item.title: Tony Hayward, Former BP Chief, Returns to Oil
item.description: Tony Hayward, the chief of BP who was accused of insensitivity and incompetence after the Gulf of Mexico oil spill of 2010, is back in the oil business and seeking redemption.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED
item.media:description: Tony Hayward, left, with Genel Energy’s chairman, Rodney Chase, at a site in the Taq Taq oil field of northern Iraq.

item.title: Raw Data: From London, a Lesson in the Benefits of Free Wi-Fi
item.description: Free Wi-Fi service, like what was offered during the London Olympics, is becoming an important tool for operators in maintaining quality mobile service during a time of skyrocketing data traffic.
item.dc:creator: By KEVIN J. O’BRIEN
